pages.title: Langlands program
pages.text:
In [[mathematics]], the '''Langlands program''' is a web of far-reaching and influential [[conjecture]]s about connections between [[number theory]] and [[geometry]]. Proposed by {{harvs|txt|authorlink=Robert Langlands|first=Robert|last=Langlands|year1=1967|year2=1970}}, it seeks to relate [[Galois group]]s in [[algebraic number theory]] to [[automorphic form]]s and [[group representation|representation theory]] of [[algebraic group]]s over [[local field]]s and [[Adele ring|adele]]s. Widely seen as the single biggest project in modern mathematical research, the Langlands program has been described by [[Edward Frenkel]] as “a kind of grand unified theory of mathematics.”<ref>{{cite web |first= |last= |title=Math Quartet Joins Forces on Unified Theory |work=[[Quanta Magazine|Quanta]] |date=December 8, 2015 |url=https://www.quantamagazine.org/math-quartet-joins-forces-on-unified-theory-20151208/ }}</ref>

==Background==
In a very broad context, the program built on existing ideas: the ''[[philosophy of cusp forms]]'' formulated a few years earlier by [[Harish-Chandra]] and {{harvs|txt|authorlink=Israel Gelfand |last=Gelfand|year=1963}}, the work and approach of Harish-Chandra on [[semisimple Lie group]]s, and in technical terms the [[Selberg trace formula|trace formula]] of [[Atle Selberg|Selberg]] and others.

What initially was very new in Langlands' work, besides technical depth, was the proposed direct connection to number theory, together with the rich organisational structure hypothesised (so-called ''[[functor|functoriality]]'').

For example, in the work of Harish-Chandra one finds the principle that what can be done for one [[Semisimple Lie algebra|semisimple]] (or reductive) [[Lie group]], should be done for all. Therefore, once the role of some low-dimensional Lie groups such as GL(2) in the theory of modular forms had been recognised, and with hindsight GL(1) in [[class field theory]], the way was open at least to speculation about GL(''n'') for general ''n'' > 2.

The ''cusp form'' idea came out of the cusps on [[modular curves]] but also had a meaning visible in [[spectral theory]] as '[[spectrum (functional analysis)|discrete spectrum]]', contrasted with the '[[spectrum (functional analysis)|continuous spectrum]]' from [[Eisenstein series]]. It becomes much more technical for bigger Lie groups, because the [[parabolic subgroup]]s are more numerous.

In all these approaches there was no shortage of technical methods, often inductive in nature and based on [[Levi decomposition]]s amongst other matters, but the field was and is very demanding.<ref>{{cite book|isbn=978-0-465-05074-1|title=Love & Math|first=Edward|last=Frenkel|date=2013|quote=All this stuff, as my dad put it, is quite heavy: we've got Hitchin moduli spaces, mirror symmetry, A-branes, B-branes, automorphic sheaves... One can get a headache just trying to keep track of them all.  Believe me, even among specialists, very few people know the nuts and bolts of all elements of this construction.}}</ref>

And on the side of modular forms, there were examples such as [[Hilbert modular form]]s, [[Siegel modular form]]s, and [[theta-function|theta-series]].

== Objects==
There are a number of related Langlands conjectures. There are many different groups over many different fields for which they can be stated, and for each field there are several different versions of the conjectures.<ref>{{citation|title=Love and Math: The Heart of Hidden Reality|first=Edward|last=Frenkel|authorlink=Edward Frenkel|publisher=Basic Books|year=2013|isbn=9780465069958|page=77|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sb0PAAAAQBAJ&pg=PT77|quote=The Langlands Program is now a vast subject. There is a large community of people working on it in different fields: number theory, harmonic analysis, geometry, representation theory, mathematical physics. Although they work with very different objects, they are all observing similar phenomena.}}</ref> Some versions{{which|date=September 2012}} of the Langlands conjectures are vague, or depend on objects such as the [[Langlands group]]s, whose existence is unproven, or on the L-group that has several inequivalent definitions. Moreover, the Langlands conjectures have evolved since Langlands first stated them in 1967.

There are different types of objects for which the Langlands conjectures can be stated:
*Representations of [[reductive group]]s over local fields (with different subcases corresponding to archimedean local fields, ''p''-adic local fields, and completions of function fields)
*Automorphic forms on reductive groups over global fields (with subcases corresponding to number fields or function fields).
*Finite fields. Langlands did not originally consider this case, but his conjectures have analogues for it.
*More general fields, such as function fields over the complex numbers.

==Conjectures==

There are several different ways of stating the Langlands conjectures, which are closely related but not obviously equivalent.

===Reciprocity===

The starting point of the program may be seen as [[Emil Artin]]'s [[Artin reciprocity|reciprocity law]], which generalizes [[quadratic reciprocity]]. The [[Artin reciprocity law]] applies to a [[Galois extension]] of an [[algebraic number field]] whose [[Galois group]] is [[abelian group|abelian]]; it assigns [[L-function]]s to the one-dimensional representations of this Galois group, and states that these L-functions are identical to certain [[Dirichlet L-series]] or more general series (that is, certain analogues of the [[Riemann zeta function]]) constructed from [[Hecke character]]s. The precise correspondence between these different kinds of L-functions constitutes Artin's reciprocity law.

For non-abelian Galois groups and higher-dimensional representations of them, one can still define L-functions in a natural way: [[Artin L-function]]s.

The insight of Langlands was to find the proper generalization of Dirichlet L-functions, which would allow the formulation of Artin's statement in this more general setting. [[Erich Hecke|Hecke]] had earlier related Dirichlet L-functions with [[automorphic form]]s ([[holomorphic function]]s on the upper half plane of '''C''' that satisfy certain functional equations). Langlands then generalized these to [[automorphic cuspidal representation]]s, which are certain infinite dimensional irreducible representations of the [[general linear group]] GL(''n'') over the [[adele ring]] of '''Q'''. (This ring simultaneously keeps track of all the completions of '''Q''', see [[p-adic number|''p''-adic numbers]].)

Langlands attached [[automorphic L-function]]s to these automorphic representations, and conjectured that every Artin L-function arising from a finite-dimensional representation of the Galois group of a [[number field]] is equal to one arising from an automorphic cuspidal representation. This is known as his "[[reciprocity law|reciprocity conjecture]]".

Roughly speaking, the reciprocity conjecture gives a correspondence between automorphic representations of a reductive group and homomorphisms from a [[Langlands group]] to an [[Langlands dual group|L-group]]. There are numerous variations of this, in part because the definitions of Langlands group and L-group are not fixed.

Over [[local field]]s this is expected to give a parameterization of [[L-packet]]s of admissible irreducible representations of a reductive group over the local field. For example, over the real numbers, this correspondence is the [[Langlands classification]] of representations of real reductive groups. Over [[global field]]s, it should give a parameterization of automorphic forms.

===Functoriality===

The functoriality conjecture states that a suitable homomorphism of L-groups is expected to give a correspondence between automorphic forms (in the global case) or representations (in the local case). Roughly speaking, the Langlands reciprocity conjecture is the special case of the functoriality conjecture when one of the reductive groups is trivial.

====Generalized functoriality====
Langlands generalized the idea of functoriality: instead of using the general linear group GL(''n''), other connected [[reductive group]]s can be used. Furthermore, given such a group ''G'', Langlands constructs the [[Langlands dual]] group <sup>L</sup>''G'', and then, for every automorphic cuspidal representation of ''G'' and every finite-dimensional representation of <sup>L</sup>''G'', he defines an L-function. One of his conjectures states that these L-functions satisfy a certain functional equation generalizing those of other known L-functions.

He then goes on to formulate a very general "Functoriality Principle". Given two reductive groups and a (well behaved) [[morphism]] between their corresponding L-groups, this conjecture relates their automorphic representations in a way that is compatible with their L-functions. This functoriality conjecture implies all the other conjectures presented so far. It is of the nature of an [[induced representation]] construction—what in the more traditional theory of [[automorphic form]]s had been called a '[[Lift (mathematics)|lifting]]', known in special cases, and so is covariant (whereas a [[restricted representation]] is contravariant). Attempts to specify a direct construction have only produced some conditional results.

All these conjectures can be formulated for more general fields in place of '''Q''': [[algebraic number field]]s (the original and most important case), [[local field]]s, and function fields (finite [[field extension|extensions]] of '''F'''<sub>''p''</sub>(''t'') where ''p'' is a [[prime number|prime]] and '''F'''<sub>''p''</sub>(''t'') is the field of rational functions over the [[finite field]] with ''p'' elements).

===Geometric conjectures===

{{main|Geometric Langlands correspondence}}

The so-called geometric Langlands program, suggested by [[Gérard Laumon]] following ideas of [[Vladimir Drinfeld]], arises from a geometric reformulation of the usual Langlands program that attempts to relate more than just irreducible representations. In simple cases, it relates ''l''-adic representations of the [[étale fundamental group]] of an [[algebraic curve]] to objects of the [[derived category]]  of ''l''-adic sheaves on the [[moduli stack of bundles|moduli stack]] of [[vector bundle]]s over the curve.

==Current status==
The Langlands conjectures for GL(1, ''K'') follow from (and are essentially equivalent to)   [[class field theory]].

Langlands proved the Langlands conjectures for groups over the archimedean local fields '''R''' and '''C''' by giving the [[Langlands classification]] of their irreducible representations.

Lusztig's classification of the irreducible representations of groups of Lie type over finite fields can be considered an analogue of the Langlands conjectures for finite fields.

[[Andrew Wiles]]' proof of modularity of semi-stable elliptic curves over rationals can be viewed as an instance of the Langlands reciprocity conjecture, since the main idea is to relate the Galois representations arising from elliptic curves to modular forms.  Although Wiles' results have been substantially generalized, in many different directions, the full Langlands conjecture for GL(2, '''Q''') remains unproved.

[[Laurent Lafforgue]] proved [[Lafforgue's theorem]] verifying the Langlands conjectures for the general linear group GL(''n'', ''K'') for function fields ''K''. This work continued earlier investigations by Drinfeld, who proved the case GL(2, ''K'').

===Local Langlands conjectures===
{{main|local Langlands conjectures}}

{{harvs|txt|last=Kutzko|first=Philip |authorlink=Philip Kutzko|year=1980}} proved the [[local Langlands conjectures]] for the general linear group GL(2, ''K'') over local fields.

{{harvs|txt|last=Laumon|first=Gérard |last2=Rapoport |authorlink=Gérard Laumon |first2=Michael |authorlink2=Michael Rapoport |last3=Stuhler |first3=Ulrich |authorlink3=Ulrich Stuhler |year=1993}} proved the local Langlands conjectures  for the general linear group GL(''n'', ''K'') for positive characteristic local fields ''K''. Their proof uses a global argument.

{{harvs|txt|authorlink=Richard Taylor (mathematician)|first=Richard|last= Taylor|first2= Michael|last2=Harris |authorlink2=Michael Harris (mathematician)|year=2001}} proved the local Langlands conjectures for the general linear group GL(''n'', ''K'') for characteristic 0 local fields ''K''. {{harvs|txt|last=Henniart|first=Guy|authorlink=Guy Henniart|year=2000}} gave another proof. Both proofs use a global argument. {{harvs|txt|authorlink=Peter Scholze|last=Scholze|first=Peter|year=2013}} gave another proof.

===Fundamental lemma===
{{main|Fundamental lemma (Langlands program)}}

In 2008, [[Ngô Bảo Châu]] proved the "[[Fundamental lemma (Langlands program)|fundamental lemma]]", which was originally conjectured by Langlands in 1983 and being required in the proof of some important conjectures in the Langlands program.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://lecourrier.vnagency.com.vn/PrintView.asp?id=49751|language=French|title=Ngô Bao Châu, sommité mondiale des maths|author=Ham Chau|publisher=''Le Courrier du Vietnam''|date=2009-02-15}}</ref><ref>{{Citation | last1=Langlands | first1=Robert P. | title=Les débuts d'une formule des traces stable | url=http://www.sunsite.ubc.ca/DigitalMathArchive/Langlands/endoscopy.html#debuts | publisher=Université de Paris VII U.E.R. de Mathématiques | location=Paris | series=Publications Mathématiques de l'Université Paris VII [Mathematical Publications of the University of Paris VII] | mr=697567  | year=1983 | volume=13}}</ref>

pages.title: Local Langlands conjectures
Orbit method
pages.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2015}}
In [[mathematics]], the '''orbit method''' (also known as the '''Kirillov theory''', '''the method of coadjoint orbits''' and by a few similar names) establishes a correspondence between irreducible [[unitary representation]]s of a [[Lie group]] and its [[coadjoint orbit]]s: orbits of the [[Group action (mathematics)|action of the group]] on the dual space of its [[Lie algebra]]. The theory was introduced by {{harvs|txt|last=Kirillov|authorlink=Alexandre Kirillov|year1=1961|year2=1962}} for [[nilpotent group]]s and later extended by [[Bertram Kostant]], [[Louis Auslander]], [[Lajos Pukánszky]] and others to the case of [[solvable group]]s. [[Roger Evans Howe|Roger Howe]] found a version of the orbit method that applies to ''p''-adic Lie groups. [[David Vogan]] proposed that the orbit method should serve as a unifying principle in the description of the unitary duals of real reductive Lie groups.

== Relation with symplectic geometry ==

One of the key observations of Kirillov was that coadjoint orbits of a Lie group ''G'' have natural structure of [[symplectic manifold]]s whose symplectic structure is invariant under ''G''. If an orbit is the [[phase space]] of a ''G''-invariant [[Hamiltonian mechanics|classical mechanical system]] then the corresponding quantum mechanical system ought to be described via an irreducible unitary representation of ''G''. Geometric invariants of the orbit translate into algebraic invariants of the corresponding representation. In this way the orbit method may be viewed as a precise mathematical manifestation of a vague physical principle of quantization. In the case of a nilpotent group ''G'' the correspondence involves all orbits, but for a general ''G'' additional restrictions on the orbit are necessary (polarizability, integrality, Pukánszky condition). This point of view has been significantly advanced by Kostant in his theory of [[geometric quantization]] of coadjoint orbits.

== Kirillov character formula ==
{{main|Kirillov character formula}}
For a [[Lie group]] <math>G</math>, the [[Kirillov orbit method]] gives a heuristic method in [[representation theory]]. It connects the [[Fourier transform]]s of [[coadjoint orbit]]s, which lie in the [[dual space]] of the [[Lie algebra]] of ''G'', to the [[infinitesimal character]]s of the [[irreducible representation]]s. The method got its name after the [[Russia]]n mathematician [[Alexandre Kirillov]].

At its simplest, it states that a character of a Lie group may be given by the [[Fourier transform]] of the [[Dirac delta function]] [[support (mathematics)|support]]ed on the coadjoint orbits, weighted by the square-root of the [[Jacobian matrix and determinant|Jacobian]] of the [[exponential map (Lie theory)|exponential map]], denoted by <math>j</math>.  It does not apply to all Lie groups, but works for a number of classes of [[connected space|connected]] Lie groups, including [[nilpotent]], some [[Semisimple Lie group|semisimple]] groups, and [[compact group]]s.

== Special cases ==

=== Nilpotent group case ===

Let ''G'' be a [[connected space|connected]], [[simply connected]] [[nilpotent group|nilpotent]] [[Lie group]]. Kirillov proved that the equivalence classes of [[irreducible representation|irreducible]] [[unitary representation]]s of ''G'' are parametrized  by the ''coadjoint orbits'' of ''G'', that is the orbits of the action ''G'' on the dual space <math> \mathfrak{g}^*</math> of its Lie algebra. The [[Kirillov character formula]] expresses the [[Harish-Chandra character]] of the representation as a certain integral over the corresponding orbit.

=== Compact Lie group case ===

Complex irreducible representations of [[compact Lie group]]s have been completely classified. They are always finite-dimensional, unitarizable (i.e. admit an invariant positive definite [[Hermitian form]]) and are parametrized by their [[highest weight]]s, which are precisely the dominant integral weights for the group. If ''G'' is a compact [[semisimple Lie group]] with a [[Cartan subalgebra]] ''h'' then its coadjoint orbits are [[closed set|closed]] and each of them intersects the positive Weyl chamber ''h''<sup>*</sup><sub>+</sub> in a single point. An orbit is '''integral''' if this point belongs to the weight lattice of ''G''.
The highest weight theory can be restated in the form of a bijection between the set of integral coadjoint orbits and the set of equivalence classes of irreducible unitary representations of ''G'': the highest weight representation ''L''(''λ'') with highest weight ''λ''∈''h''<sup>*</sup><sub>+</sub> corresponds to the integral coadjoint orbit ''G''·''λ''. The [[Kirillov character formula]] amounts to the character formula earlier proved by [[Harish-Chandra]].

== See also ==

*[[Dixmier mapping]]
*[[Pukánszky condition]]

== References ==
*{{Citation | last1=Dulfo | last2=Pederson| last3=Vergne| title=The Orbit Method in Representation Theory: Proceedings of a Conference Held in Copenhagen, August to September 1988 (Progress in Mathematics)|year=1990 | publisher=  Birkhäuser}}
*{{Citation | last1=Kirillov | first1=A. A. | title=Unitary representations of nilpotent Lie groups |mr=0125908 | year=1961 | journal=Doklady Akademii Nauk SSSR | issn=0002-3264 | volume=138 | pages=283–284}}
*{{Citation | last1=Kirillov | first1=A. A. | title=Unitary representations of nilpotent Lie groups | doi=10.1070/RM1962v017n04ABEH004118 |mr=0142001 | year=1962 | journal=Russian Mathematical Surveys | issn=0042-1316 | volume=17 | issue=4 | pages=53–104}}
*{{Citation | last1=Kirillov | first1=A. A. | title=Elements of the theory of representations | origyear=1972 | publisher=[[Springer-Verlag]] | location=Berlin, New York | series= Grundlehren der Mathematischen Wissenschaften | isbn=978-0-387-07476-4 |mr=0412321 | year=1976 | volume=220}}
* {{citation|title=Merits and demerits of the orbit method|first=A. A.|last=Kirillov|journal=Bull. Amer. Math. Soc.|volume=36|issue=4|year=1999|pages=433–488|url=http://www.ams.org/bull/1999-36-04/S0273-0979-99-00849-6/home.html|doi=10.1090/s0273-0979-99-00849-6}}.
*{{eom|id=O/o070020|first=A. A.|last=Kirillov}}
* {{citation|last=Kirillov|first=A. A.|title=Lectures on the orbit method|series=[[Graduate Studies in Mathematics]]|volume=64|publisher=American Mathematical Society|location=Providence, RI|year=2004|isbn=978-0-8218-3530-2}}.

pages.title: Plancherel theorem for spherical functions
pages.text:
In [[mathematics]], the '''Plancherel theorem for spherical functions''' is an important result in the [[group representation|representation theory]] of [[semisimple Lie group]]s, due in its final form to [[Harish-Chandra]]. It is a natural generalisation in [[non-commutative harmonic analysis]] of the [[Plancherel formula]] and [[Fourier inversion formula]] in the representation theory of the group of real numbers in classical [[harmonic analysis]] and has a similarly close interconnection with the theory of [[differential equation]]s.
It is the special case for [[zonal spherical function]]s of the general [[Plancherel theorem]] for semisimple Lie groups, also proved by Harish-Chandra. The Plancherel theorem gives the [[Spectral theory|eigenfunction expansion]] of radial functions for the [[Laplacian operator]] on the associated [[symmetric space]] ''X''; it also gives the [[direct integral|direct integral decomposition]] into [[irreducible representation]]s of the [[regular representation]] on L<sup>2</sup>(''X''). In the case of
[[hyperbolic space]], these expansions were known from [[Spectral theory of ordinary differential equations#Application to the hypergeometric equation|prior results]] of Mehler, [[Weyl]] and [[Vladimir Fock|Fock]].
 
The main reference for almost all this material is the encyclopedic text of {{harvtxt|Helgason|1984}}.

==History==
The first versions of an abstract Plancherel formula for the Fourier transform on a [[unimodular group|unimodular]] [[locally compact group]] ''G'' were due to Segal and Mautner.<ref>{{harvnb|Helgason|1984|pp=492–493}}, historical notes on the Plancherel theorem for spherical functions</ref> At around the same time, Harish-Chandra<ref>{{harvnb|Harish-Chandra|1951}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Harish-Chandra|1952}}</ref> and Gelfand & Naimark<ref>{{harvnb|Gelfand|Naimark|1948}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Guillemin|Sternberg|1977}}</ref> derived an explicit formula for [[SL(2,R)]] and complex [[semisimple Lie group]]s, so in particular the [[Lorentz group]]s. A simpler abstract formula was derived by Mautner for a "topological" symmetric space ''G''/''K'' corresponding to a [[maximal compact subgroup]] ''K''. [[Roger Godement|Godement]] gave a more concrete and satisfactory form for [[positive definite function on a group|positive definite]] [[zonal spherical function|spherical functions]], a class of [[special function]]s on ''G''/''K''. Since when ''G'' is a [[semisimple Lie group]] these spherical functions φ<sub>λ</sub> were naturally labelled by a parameter λ in the quotient of a [[Euclidean space]] by the action of a [[finite reflection group]], it became a central problem to determine explicitly the [[Plancherel measure]] in terms of this parametrization. Generalizing the ideas of [[Hermann Weyl]] from the [[spectral theory of ordinary differential equations]], Harish-Chandra<ref name="HarishChandra1958">{{harvnb|Harish-Chandra|1958a}}</ref><ref name="HarishChandra1958a">{{harvnb|Harish-Chandra|1958b}}</ref> introduced his celebrated '''c-function''' ''c''(λ) to describe the asymptotic behaviour of the spherical functions φ<sub>λ</sub> and proposed ''c''(λ)<sup>−2</sup> ''d''λ as the Plancherel measure. He verified this formula for the special cases when ''G'' is complex or [[Iwasawa decomposition|real rank]] one, thus in particular covering the case when ''G''/''K'' is a [[hyperbolic space]]. The general case was reduced to two conjectures about the properties of the c-function and the so-called spherical Fourier transform. Explicit formulas for the c-function were later obtained for a large class of classical semisimple Lie groups by Bhanu-Murthy. In turn these formulas prompted Gindikin and Karpelevič to derive a product formula<ref>{{harvnb|Gindikin|Karpelevič|1962}}</ref> for the c-function, reducing the computation to Harish-Chandra's formula for the rank 1 case. Their work finally enabled Harish-Chandra to complete his proof of the Plancherel theorem for spherical functions in 1966.<ref>{{harvnb|Harish-Chandra|1966}}, section 21</ref>

In many special cases, for example for complex semisimple group or the Lorentz groups, there are simple methods to develop the theory directly. Certain subgroups of these groups can be treated by techniques generalising the well-known "[[method of descent]]" due to [[Jacques Hadamard]]. In particular {{harvtxt|Flensted-Jensen|1978}} gave a general method for deducing properties of the spherical transform for a real semisimple group from that of its complexification.

One of the principal applications and motivations for the spherical transform was [[Selberg's trace formula]]. The classical [[Poisson summation formula]] combines the Fourier inversion formula on a vector group with summation over a cocompact lattice. In Selberg's analogue of this formula, the vector group is replaced by ''G''/''K'', the Fourier transform by the spherical transform and the lattice by a cocompact (or cofinite) discrete subgroup. The original paper of {{harvtxt|Selberg|1956}} implicitly invokes the spherical transform; it was {{harvtxt|Godement|1957}} who brought the transform to the fore, giving in particular an elementary treatment for SL(2,'''R''') along the lines sketched by Selberg.

==Spherical functions==
{{main article|Zonal spherical function}}
Let ''G'' be a [[semisimple Lie algebra|semisimple]] [[Lie group]] and ''K'' a [[maximal compact subgroup]] of ''G''. The [[Hecke algebra of a locally compact group|Hecke algebra]] 
''C''<sub>c</sub>(''K'' \''G''/''K''), consisting of compactly supported ''K''-biinvariant continuous functions on ''G'', acts by convolution on the [[Hilbert space]] ''H''=''L''<sup>2</sup>(''G'' / ''K''). Because ''G'' / ''K'' is a [[symmetric space]], this *-algebra is [[commutative]]. The closure of its (the Hecke algebra's) image in the operator norm is a non-unital commutative [[C* algebra]] <math>\mathfrak{A}</math>, so by the [[Gelfand isomorphism]] can be identified with the continuous functions vanishing at infinity on its [[spectrum]] ''X''.<ref>The spectrum coincides with that of the commutative Banach *-algebra of integrable ''K''-biinvariant functions on ''G'' under convolution, a dense *-subalgebra of <math>\mathfrak{A}</math>.</ref> Points in the spectrum are given by continuous *-homomorphisms of <math>\mathfrak{A}</math> into '''C''', i.e. [[Gelfand isomorphism|characters]] of <math>\mathfrak{A}</math>.

If ''S''' denotes the [[commutant]] of a set of operators ''S'' on ''H'', then <math>\mathfrak{A}^\prime</math> can be identified with the commutant of the [[regular representation]] of ''G'' on ''H''. Now <math>\mathfrak{A}</math> leaves invariant the subspace ''H''<sub>0</sub> of ''K''-invariant vectors in ''H''. Moreover the [[abelian von Neumann algebra]] it generates on ''H''<sub>0</sub> is maximal Abelian. By [[spectral theory]], there is an essentially unique<ref>The [[Equivalence (measure theory)|measure class]] of μ in the sense of the [[Radon–Nikodym theorem]] is unique.</ref> [[Measure (mathematics)|measure]] μ on the [[locally compact]] space ''X'' and a unitary transformation ''U'' between ''H''<sub>0</sub> and ''L''<sup>2</sup>(''X'', μ) which carries the operators in <math>\mathfrak{A}</math> onto the corresponding [[multiplication operator]]s.

The transformation ''U'' is called the '''spherical Fourier transform''' or sometimes just the '''spherical transform''' and μ is called the '''[[Plancherel measure]]'''. The Hilbert space ''H''<sub>0</sub> can be identified with ''L''<sup>2</sup>(''K''\''G''/''K''), the space of ''K''-biinvariant square integrable functions on ''G''.

The characters χ<sub>λ</sub> of <math>\mathfrak{A}</math> (i.e. the points of ''X'') can be described by [[positive definite function on a group|positive definite]] [[zonal spherical function|spherical functions]] φ<sub>λ</sub> on ''G'', via the formula

:<math> \chi_\lambda(\pi(f)) = \int_G f(g)\cdot \varphi_\lambda(g) \, dg.</math>

for ''f'' in ''C''<sub>c</sub>(''K''\''G''/''K''), where π(''f'') denotes the convolution operator in <math>\mathfrak{A}</math> and the integral is with respect to [[Haar measure]] on ''G''.

The spherical functions φ<sub>λ</sub> on ''G'' are given by [[Zonal spherical function#Harish-Chandra's formula|Harish-Chandra's formula]]:

:{| border="1" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="5"
|<math>\varphi_\lambda(g) = \int_K \lambda^\prime(gk)^{-1}\, dk. </math>
|}

In this formula:

* the integral is with respect to Haar measure on ''K'';
* λ is an element of ''A''* =Hom(''A'','''T''') where ''A'' is the Abelian vector subgroup in the [[Iwasawa decomposition]] ''G'' =''KAN'' of ''G'';
* λ' is defined on ''G'' by first extending λ to a [[character (mathematics)|character]] of the [[solvable group|solvable subgroup]] ''AN'', using the group homomorphism onto ''A'', and then setting

::<math>\lambda^\prime(kx) = \Delta_{AN}(x)^{1/2} \lambda(x)</math>

:for ''k'' in ''K'' and ''x'' in ''AN'', where Δ<sub>''AN''</sub> is the [[Haar measure#The modular function|modular function]] of ''AN''.

* Two different characters λ<sub>1</sub> and λ<sub>2</sub> give the same spherical function if and only if λ<sub>1</sub> = λ<sub>2</sub>·''s'', where ''s'' is in the [[Weyl group]] of ''A''

::<math> W=N_K(A)/C_K(A),</math>

:the quotient of the [[normaliser]] of ''A'' in ''K'' by its [[centraliser]], a [[finite reflection group]].

It follows that

* '''''X'' can be identified with the quotient space ''A''*/''W'''''.

==Spherical principal series==
{{see also|Principal series representation}}
The spherical function φ<sub>λ</sub> can be identified with the matrix coefficient of the '''spherical principal series''' of ''G''. If ''M'' is the [[centralizer]] of ''A'' in ''K'', this is defined as the unitary representation π<sub>λ</sub> of ''G'' [[induced representation|induced]] by the character of ''B'' = ''MAN'' given by the composition of the homomorphism of ''MAN'' onto ''A'' and the character λ.
The induced representation is defined on functions ''f'' on ''G'' with

:<math> f(gb)=\Delta(b)^{1/2} \lambda(b) f(g)</math>

for ''b'' in ''B'' by

:<math>\pi(g)f(x)=f(g^{-1}x),</math>

where

:<math> \|f\|^2 = \int_K |f(k)|^2 \, dk < \infty.</math>

The functions ''f'' can be identified with functions in L<sup>2</sup>(''K'' / ''M'') and

:<math> \chi_\lambda(g)=(\pi(g)1,1).</math>

As {{harvtxt|Kostant|1969}} proved, the representations of the spherical principal series are irreducible and two representations π<sub>λ</sub> and 
π<sub>μ</sub> are unitarily equivalent if and only if μ = σ(λ) for some σ in the Weyl group of ''A''.

==Example: SL(2,C)==
The group ''G'' = SL(2,'''C''') acts transitively on the [[quaternion]]ic upper half space

:<math>\mathfrak{H}^3=\{x+y i + t j|t>0\}</math>

by [[Möbius transformation]]s. The complex matrix

:<math>g=\begin{pmatrix} a & b \\ c& d \end{pmatrix}</math>

acts as

:<math>g(w)=(aw+b)(cw +d)^{-1}.\ </math>

The stabiliser of the point '''j''' is the maximal compact subgroup ''K'' = SU(2), so that <math>\mathfrak{H}^3</math> = ''G'' / ''K''.
It carries the ''G''-invariant [[Riemannian metric]]

:<math> ds^2 =r^{-2}(dx^2 + dy^2 + dr^2)\ </math>

with associated volume element

:<math> dV= r^{-3}\, dx\,dy\,dr</math>

and [[Laplacian operator]]

:<math> \Delta = -r^2(\partial_x^2 + \partial_y^2 + \partial_r^2) + r\partial_r.</math>

Every point in <math>\mathfrak{H}^3</math> can be written as ''k''(''e''<sup>''t''</sup>'''j''') with ''k'' in SU(2) and ''t'' determined up to a sign.
The Laplacian has the following form on functions invariant under SU(2), regarded as functions of the real parameter ''t'':
 
:<math> \Delta= - \partial_t^2 - 2 \coth t \partial_t.</math>

The integral of an SU(2)-invariant function is given by

:<math>\int f \, dV= \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} f(t) \, \sinh^2 t \, dt.</math>

Identifying the square integrable SU(2)-invariant functions with L<sup>2</sup>('''R''') by the unitary transformation ''Uf''(''t'') = ''f''(''t'') sinh ''t'', Δ is transformed into the operator

:<math>U^*\Delta U = -{d^2\over dt^2} + 1.</math>

By the [[Plancherel theorem]] and [[Fourier inversion formula]] for '''R''', any SU(2)-invariant function ''f'' can be expressed in terms of the spherical functions

:<math>\Phi_\lambda(t)={\sin \lambda t\over \lambda \sinh t},</math>

by the spherical transform

:<math>\tilde{f}(\lambda)=\int f \Phi_{-\lambda} \, dV</math>

and the spherical inversion formula

:<math>f(x)=\int \tilde{f}(\lambda)\Phi_\lambda(x) \lambda^2 \,d\lambda.</math>

Taking <math>f= f_2^*\star f_1</math> with ''f''<sub>''i''</sub> in C<sub>c</sub>(''G'' / ''K'') and <math> f^*(g)=\overline{f(g^{-1})}</math>, and evaluating at ''i'' yields the ''Plancherel formula''

:<math> \int_G f_1\overline{f_2} \, dg = \int \tilde{f}_1(\lambda) \overline{\tilde{f}_2(\lambda)}\, \lambda^2 \, d\lambda.</math>

For biinvariant functions this establishes the '''Plancherel theorem for spherical functions''': the map

:<math> U:f\mapsto \tilde{f},\,\, L^2(K\backslash G/K) \rightarrow L^2({\mathbb R}, \lambda^2\,d\lambda)</math>

is unitary and sends the convolution operator defined by <math> f\in</math> L<sup>1</sup>(''K'' \ ''G'' / ''K'') into the multiplication operator defined by <math>\tilde{f}</math>.

The spherical function Φ<sub>λ</sub> is an [[eigenfunction]] of the Laplacian:

:<math>\displaystyle{\Delta \Phi_\lambda= (\lambda^2 + 1) \Phi_\lambda.}</math>

[[Schwartz function]]s on '''R''' are the spherical transforms of functions ''f'' belonging to the Harish-Chandra Schwartz space

:<math> {\mathcal S} =\{f| \sup_t |(1+t^2)^N(I+\Delta)^M f(t)\sinh(t)|<\infty\}.</math>

By the [[Paley-Wiener theorem]], the spherical transforms of smooth SU(2)-invariant functions of [[compact support]] are precisely
functions on '''R''' which are restrictions of [[holomorphic function]]s on '''C''' satisfying an exponential growth condition

:<math>|F(\lambda)|\le C e^{ R \cdot |{\rm Im}\,\lambda|}.</math>

As a function on ''G'', Φ<sub>λ</sub> is the matrix coefficient of the spherical principal series defined on L<sup>2</sup>('''C'''), where '''C''' is identified with the boundary of <math>\mathfrak{H}^3</math>. The representation is given by the formula

:<math>\pi_\lambda(g^{-1})\xi(z)=|cz + d|^{-2-i\lambda} \xi(g(z)).</math>

The function

:<math>\xi_0(z)=\pi^{-1} (1+|z|^2)^{-2}</math>

is fixed by SU(2) and

:<math>\Phi_\lambda(g)=(\pi_\lambda(g)\xi_0,\xi_0).</math>

The representations π<sub>λ</sub> are irreducible and unitarily equivalent only when the sign of λ is changed. 
The map ''W'' of <math> L^2({\mathfrak H}^3)</math> onto L<sup>2</sup>([0,∞) x'''C''') (with measure λ<sup>2</sup> ''d''λ on the first factor) given by

:<math> Wf(\lambda,z)= \int_{G/K} f(g) \pi_\lambda(g)\xi_0(z) \, dg</math>

is unitary and gives the decomposition of <math> L^2({\mathfrak H}^3)</math> as a [[direct integral]] of the spherical principal series.

==Example: SL(2,R)==
The group ''G'' = SL(2,'''R''') acts transitively on the Poincaré upper half plane

:<math>\mathfrak{H}^2=\{x+r i|r>0\}</math>

by [[Möbius transformation]]s. The complex matrix

:<math>g=\begin{pmatrix} a & b \\ c& d \end{pmatrix}</math>

acts as

:<math>g(w)=(aw+b)(cw +d)^{-1}.</math>

The stabiliser of the point '''i''' is the maximal compact subgroup ''K'' = SO(2), so that <math>\mathfrak{H}^2</math> = ''G'' / ''K''.
It carries the ''G''-invariant [[Riemannian metric]]

:<math> ds^2 =r^{-2}(dx^2 + dr^2)</math>

with associated area element

:<math> dA= r^{-2}\, dx\,dr</math>

and [[Laplacian operator]]

:<math> \Delta = -r^2(\partial_x^2 + \partial_r^2).</math>

Every point in <math>\mathfrak{H}^2</math> can be written as ''k''( ''e''<sup>''t''</sup> '''i''' ) with ''k'' in SO(2) and ''t'' determined up to a sign. The Laplacian has the following form on functions invariant under SO(2), regarded as functions of the real parameter ''t'':
 
:<math> \Delta= - \partial_t^2 - \coth t \partial_t.</math>

The integral of an SO(2)-invariant function is given by
 
:<math>\int f \, dA= \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} f(t) \, |\sinh t| \, dt.</math>

There are several methods for deriving the corresponding eigenfunction expansion for this ordinary differential equation including:

# the classical [[spectral theory of ordinary differential equations]] applied to the [[Spectral theory of ordinary differential equations#Application to the hypergeometric equation|hypergeometric equation]] (Mehler, Weyl, Fock);
# variants of Hadamard's method of descent, realising 2-dimensional hyperbolic space as the quotient of 3-dimensional hyperbolic space by the free action of a 1-parameter subgroup of SL(2,'''C''');
# Abel's integral equation, following Selberg and Godement;
# orbital integrals (Harish-Chandra, Gelfand & Naimark).

The second and third technique will be described below, with two different methods of descent: the classical one due Hadamard, familiar from treatments of the heat equation<ref>{{harvnb|Davies|1990}}</ref> and the wave equation<ref>{{harvnb|Lax|Phillips|1976}}</ref> on hyperbolic space; and Flensted-Jensen's method on the hyperboloid.

===Hadamard's method of descent===

If ''f''(''x'',''r'') is a function on <math>\mathfrak{H}^2</math> and

:<math>M_1f(x,y,r)=r^{1/2}\cdot f(x,r)</math>

then

:<math> \Delta_3 M_1 f= M_1(\Delta_2 + {3\over 4})f,</math>

where Δ<sub>''n''</sub> is the Laplacian on <math>{\mathfrak H}^n</math>.

Since the action of SL(2,'''C''') commutes with Δ<sub>3</sub>, the operator
''M''<sub>0</sub> on S0(2)-invariant functions obtained by averaging ''M''<sub>1</sub>''f'' by the action of SU(2)
also satisfies

:<math> \Delta_3 M_0= M_0(\Delta_2 + {3\over 4}).</math>

The adjoint operator ''M''<sub>1</sub>* defined by

:<math> M_1^* F(x,r)=r^{1/2} \int_{-\infty}^\infty F(x,y,r)\, dy</math>

satisfies

:<math> \int_{\mathfrak{H}^3} (M_1f)\cdot F \,dV = \int_{\mathfrak{H}^2} f\cdot (M_1^*F) \,dA.</math>

The adjoint ''M''<sub>0</sub>*, defined by averaging ''M''*''f'' over SO(2), satisfies

:<math> \int_{\mathfrak{H}^3} (M_0f)\cdot F \,dV = \int_{\mathfrak{H}^2} f\cdot (M_0^*F) \,dA</math>

for SU(2)-invariant functions ''F'' and SO(2)-invariant functions ''f''. It follows that
 
:<math> M_i^* \Delta_3= (\Delta_2 + {3\over 4})M_i^*.</math>

The function

:<math> \displaystyle{f_\lambda= M_1^* \Phi_\lambda} </math>

is SO(2)-invariant and satisfies

:<math>\Delta_2 f_\lambda= (\lambda^2 +{1\over 4})f_\lambda.</math>

On the other hand,

:<math>b(\lambda)=f_\lambda(i)=\int {\sin \lambda t \over \lambda \sinh t} \, dt= {\pi\over \lambda} \tanh{\pi\lambda\over 2},</math>

since the integral can be computed by integrating <math> e^{i\lambda t} /\sinh t</math> around the rectangular 
indented contour with vertices at ±''R'' and ±''R'' + πi. Thus the eigenfunction

:<math>\displaystyle{\phi_\lambda=b(\lambda)^{-1} M_1\Phi_\lambda}</math>

satisfies the normalisation condition φ<sub>λ</sub>(''i'') = 1. There can only be
one such solution either because the [[Wronskian]] of the ordinary differential equation
must vanish or by expanding as a power series in sinh ''r''.<ref>{{harvnb|Helgason|1984|page=38}}</ref>
It follows that

:<math> \varphi_\lambda(e^t i)={1\over 2\pi}\int_0^{2\pi} (\cosh t - \sinh t \cos \theta)^{-1-i\lambda} \, d\theta.</math>

Similarly it follows that

:<math> \displaystyle{\Phi_\lambda = M_1 \phi_\lambda.}</math>

If the spherical transform of an SO(2)-invariant function on <math>\mathfrak{H}^2</math> is defined by

:<math>\tilde{f}(\lambda)=\int f \varphi_{-\lambda} \,dA,</math>

then

:<math> {(M_1^* F)}^\sim(\lambda) = \tilde{F}(\lambda).</math>

Taking ''f''=''M''<sub>1</sub>*''F'', the SL(2,'''C''') inversion formula for ''F'' immediately yields

:<math>f(x)=\int_{-\infty}^\infty \varphi_\lambda(x) \tilde{f}(\lambda)\,{\lambda \pi\over 2} \tanh({\pi\lambda\over 2})\, d\lambda,</math>

the spherical inversion formula for SO(2)-invariant functions on <math>\mathfrak{H}^2</math>.

As for SL(2,'''C'''), this immediately implies the Plancherel formula for ''f''<sub>i</sub> in C<sub>c</sub>(SL(2,'''R''') / SO(2)):

:<math>\int_{\mathfrak{H}^2} f_1\overline{f_2} \,dA = \int_{-\infty}^\infty \tilde{f}_1 \overline{\tilde{f}_2} 
\,{\lambda \pi\over 2} \tanh({\pi\lambda\over 2})\, d\lambda.</math>

The spherical function φ<sub>λ</sub> is an [[eigenfunction]] of the Laplacian:

:<math>\displaystyle{\Delta_2 \varphi_\lambda= (\lambda^2 + {1\over 4}) \varphi_\lambda.}</math>

[[Schwartz function]]s on '''R''' are the spherical transforms of functions ''f'' belonging to the Harish-Chandra Schwartz space

:<math> {\mathcal S} =\{f| \sup_t |(1+t^2)^N(I+\Delta)^M f(t)\varphi_0(t)|<\infty\}.</math>

The spherical transforms of smooth SO(2)-invariant functions of [[compact support]] are precisely
functions on '''R''' which are restrictions of [[holomorphic function]]s on '''C''' satisfying an exponential growth condition

:<math>|F(\lambda)|\le C e^{ R \cdot |{\rm Im}\,\lambda|}.</math>

Both these results can be deduced by descent from the corresponding results for SL(2,'''C'''),<ref name="FlenstedJensen1978">{{harvnb|Flensted-Jensen|1978}}</ref> 
by verifying directly that the spherical transform satisfies the given growth conditions<ref>{{harvnb|Anker|1991}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Jorgenson|Lang|2001}}</ref> and then using the relation <math> {(M_1^* F)}^\sim = \tilde{F}</math>.

As a function on ''G'', φ<sub>λ</sub> is the matrix coefficient of the spherical principal series defined on L<sup>2</sup>('''R'''), where '''R''' is identified with the boundary of <math>\mathfrak{H}^2</math>. The representation is given by the formula

:<math>\pi_\lambda(g^{-1})\xi(x)=|cx + d|^{-1-i\lambda} \xi(g(x)).</math>

The function

:<math>\xi_0(x)=\pi^{-1} (1+|x|^2)^{-1}</math>

is fixed by S0(2) and

:<math>\Phi_\lambda(g)=(\pi_\lambda(g)\xi_0,\xi_0).</math>

The representations π<sub>λ</sub> are irreducible and unitarily equivalent only when the sign of λ is changed. 
The map ''W'' of <math> L^2({\mathfrak H}^2)</math> onto L<sup>2</sup>([0,∞) x'''R'''), with measure

:<math> {\pi\lambda/2}\cdot \tanh(\pi\lambda/2) d\lambda</math>

on the first factor, is given by the formula

:<math> Wf(\lambda,x)= \int_{G/K} f(g) \pi_\lambda(g)\xi_0(x) \, dg</math>

is unitary and gives the decomposition of <math> L^2({\mathfrak H}^2)</math> as a [[direct integral]] of the spherical principal series.

===Flensted–Jensen's method of descent===

Hadamard's method of descent relied on functions invariant under the action of 1-parameter subgroup of translations in the ''y'' parameter in 
<math>\mathfrak{H}^3</math>. Flensted–Jensen's method uses the centraliser of SO(2) in SL(2,'''C''') which splits as a direct product of SO(2) 
and the 1-parameter subgroup ''K''<sub>1</sub> of matrices

:<math>g_t=\begin{pmatrix} \cosh t & i\sinh t \\ -i\sinh t& \cosh t\end{pmatrix}.</math>

The symmetric space SL(2,'''C''')/SU(2) can be identified with the space '''H'''<sup>3</sup> of positive 2×2 matrices ''A'' with determinant 1

:<math>A=\begin{pmatrix} a+b & x+iy \\ x-iy & a -b\end{pmatrix}</math>

with the group action given by

:<math>g\cdot A = gAg^*. \, </math>

Thus

:<math> g_t\cdot A=\begin{pmatrix} a \cosh 2t +y \sinh 2t +b & x+i(y\cosh 2t + a\sinh 2t) \\ x-i(y\cosh 2t + a\sinh 2t) & a\cosh 2t +y \sinh 2t -b\end{pmatrix}.</math>

So on the [[hyperboloid]] <math>a^2=1+b^2 +x^2 +y^2 </math>, ''g''<sub>''t''</sub> only changes the coordinates ''y'' and ''a''. Similarly the action of SO(2) acts by rotation on the coordinates (''b'',''x'') leaving ''a'' and ''y'' unchanged. The space '''H'''<sup>2</sup> of real-valued positive matrices ''A'' with ''y'' = 0 can be identified with the orbit of the identity matrix under SL(2,'''R'''). Taking coordinates (''b'',''x'',''y'') in '''H'''<sup>3</sup> and (''b'',''x'') on '''H'''<sup>2</sup> the volume and area elements are given by

:<math>dV =(1+r^2)^{-1/2} \,db\, dx\, dy,\,\,\, dA= (1+r^2)^{-1/2} \,db\, dx,</math>

where ''r''<sup>2</sup> equals ''b''<sup>2</sup> + ''x''<sup>2</sup> + ''y''<sup>2</sup> or ''b''<sup>2</sup> + ''x''<sup>2</sup>,
so that ''r'' is related to hyperbolic distance from the origin by <math> r =\sinh t</math>.

The [[Laplacian operator]]s are given by the formula

:<math>\Delta_n=-L_n - R_n^2 -(n-1)R_n, \, </math>

where

:<math>L_2=\partial_b^2 +\partial_x^2, \,\,\, R_2=b\partial_b + x\partial_x</math>

and

:<math>L_3=\partial_b^2 +\partial_x^2 +\partial_y^2,\,\, \, R_3=b\partial_b + x\partial_x + y\partial_y. \, </math>

For an SU(2)-invariant function ''F'' on '''H'''<sup>3</sup> and an SO(2)-invariant function on '''H'''<sup>2</sup>, regarded as
functions of ''r'' or ''t'',

:<math>\int_{H^3} F \,dV =4\pi \int_{-\infty}^\infty F(t) \sinh^2 t \, dt,\,\,\, \int_{H^2} f \,dV =2\pi\int_{-\infty}^\infty f(t) \sinh t \, dt.</math>

If ''f''(''b'',''x'') is a function on '''H'''<sup>2</sup>, ''Ef'' is defined by

:<math>Ef(b,x,y)=f(b,x). \, </math>

Thus

:<math>\Delta_3 Ef = E(\Delta_2 - R_2)f. \, </math>

If ''f'' is SO(2)-invariant, then, regarding ''f'' as a function of ''r'' or ''t'',

:<math> (-\Delta_2 +R_2)f= \partial_t^2 f + \coth t \partial _t f + r\partial_r f =\partial_t^2 f + (\coth t + \tanh t)\partial_t f.</math>

On the other hand,
 
:<math>\partial_t^2 + (\coth t + \tanh t)\partial_t =\partial_t^2 + 2 \coth(2t) \partial_t.</math>

Thus, setting ''Sf''(''t'') = ''f''(2''t''),

:<math>\displaystyle{(\Delta_2 -R_2)Sf=4S\Delta_2f},</math>

leading to the fundamental ''descent relation'' of Flensted-Jensen for ''M''<sub>0</sub> = ''ES'':

:<math>\displaystyle{\Delta_3 M_0 f=4M_0\Delta_2 f.}</math>

The same relation holds with ''M''<sub>0</sub> by ''M'', where ''Mf'' is obtained by averaging ''M''<sub>0</sub>''f'' over SU(2).

The extension ''Ef'' is constant in the ''y'' variable and therefore invariant under the transformations ''g''<sub>''s''</sub>. On the other hand, for
''F'' a suitable function on '''H'''<sup>3</sup>, the function ''QF'' defined by

:<math> QF = \int_{K_1}F\circ g_s \, ds</math>

is independent of the ''y'' variable. A straightforward change of variables shows that

:<math> \int_{H^3}F \, dV = \int_{H^2} (1+b^2 +x^2)^{1/2} QF \, dA.</math>

Since ''K''<sub>1</sub> commutes with SO(2), ''QF'' is SO(2)--invariant if ''F'' is, in particular if ''F'' is SU(2)-invariant. In this case ''QF'' is a function of ''r'' or ''t'', so that ''M''*''F'' can be defined by

:<math> M^*F(t)=QF(t/2).</math>

The integral formula above then yields

:<math>\int_{H^3} F \, dV = \int_{H^2} M^*F \, dA</math>

and hence, since for ''f'' SO(2)-invariant,

:<math>M^*((Mf)\cdot F) =f \cdot (M^*F),</math>

the following adjoint formula:

:<math>\int_{H^3} (Mf)\cdot F \, dV =\int_{H^2} f\cdot (M*F)\, dV.</math>

As a consequence

:<math>M^*\Delta_3=4\Delta_2M^*.</math>

Thus, as in the case of Hadamard's method of descent.

:<math>M^*\Phi_{2\lambda} =b(\lambda) \varphi_\lambda</math>
 
with

:<math>\displaystyle{b(\lambda)=M^*\Phi_{2\lambda}(0)=\pi \tanh \pi \lambda}</math>

and

:<math>\Phi_{2\lambda}=M\varphi_\lambda.</math>

It follows that

:<math> {(M^* F)}^\sim(\lambda) = \tilde{F}(2\lambda).</math>

Taking ''f''=''M''*''F'', the SL(2,'''C''') inversion formula for ''F'' then immediately yields

:<math>f(x)=\int_{-\infty}^\infty \varphi_\lambda(x) \tilde{f}(\lambda)\,{\lambda \pi\over 2} \tanh({\pi\lambda\over 2})\, d\lambda,</math>

===Abel's integral equation===

The spherical function φ<sub>λ</sub> is given by

:<math>\varphi_\lambda(g)=\int_K \alpha^\prime(kg) \, dk,</math>

so that

:<math> \tilde{f}(\lambda)=\int_S f(s) \alpha^\prime(s)\, ds,</math>

Thus

:<math>\tilde{f}(\lambda)=\int_{-\infty}^\infty \int_0^\infty f((a^2 + a^{-2} +b^2)/2)a^{-i\lambda/2} \, da\,db,</math>

so that defining ''F'' by

:<math>F(u)=\int_{-\infty}^\infty f(u +{t^2\over 2}) \, dt,</math>

the spherical transform can be written

:<math>\tilde{f}(\lambda)=\int_0^\infty F({a^2+a^{-2}\over 2}) a^{-i\lambda}\, da= \int_0^\infty F(\cosh t)e^{-it\lambda} \, dt.</math>

The relation between ''F'' and ''f'' is classically inverted by the [[Abel integral equation]]:

:<math>f(x)={-1\over 2\pi}\int_{-\infty}^\infty F^\prime(x +{t^2\over 2})\, dt.</math>

In fact<ref>{{harvnb|Helgason|1984|page=41}}</ref>

:<math>\int_{-\infty}^\infty F^\prime(x+{t^2\over 2})\, dt = \int_{-\infty}^\infty \int_{-\infty}^\infty f^\prime(x +{t^2 + u^2\over 2}) \, dt\,du
={2\pi} \int_0^\infty f^\prime(x+{r^2\over 2}) r\, dr= 2\pi f(x).</math>

The relation between ''F'' and <math>\tilde{f}</math> is inverted by the [[Fourier inversion formula]]:

:<math>F(\cosh t)={2\over \pi} \int_0^\infty\tilde{f}(i\lambda)\cos(\lambda t) \, d\lambda.</math>

Hence

:<math>f(i)={1\over 2\pi^2} \int_0^\infty \tilde{f}(\lambda) \lambda\, d\lambda \int_{-\infty}^\infty {\sin \lambda t/2\over \sinh t} \cosh {t\over 2} \, dt ={1\over 2\pi^2} \int_{-\infty}^\infty \tilde{f}(\lambda) {\lambda\pi\over 2} \tanh({\pi\lambda\over 2})\, d\lambda.</math>

This gives the spherical inversion for the point ''i''. Now for fixed ''g'' in SL(2,'''R''') define<ref>{{harvnb|Helgason|1984|page=46}}</ref>

:<math>f_1(w)=\int_K f(gkw) \, dk,</math>

another rotation invariant function on <math>\mathfrak{H}^2</math> with ''f''<sub>1</sub>(i)=''f''(''g''(''i'')). On the other hand, for biinvariant functions ''f'',

:<math>\pi_\lambda(f)\xi_0 =\tilde{f}(\lambda) \xi_0</math>

so that

:<math> \tilde{f}_1(\lambda)=\tilde{f}(\lambda)\cdot \varphi_\lambda(w),</math>

where ''w'' = ''g''(''i''). Combining this with the above inversion formula for ''f''<sub>1</sub> yields the general spherical inversion formula:

:<math> f(w) ={1\over \pi^2} \int_0^\infty \tilde{f}(\lambda) \varphi_\lambda(w) {\lambda\pi\over 2} \tanh({\pi\lambda\over 2})\, d\lambda.</math>

==Other special cases==
All complex semisimple Lie groups or the [[Lorentz group]]s SO<sup>0</sup>(''N'',1) with ''N'' odd can be treated directly by reduction to the usual Fourier transform.<ref name="FlenstedJensen1978" /><ref>{{harvnb|Takakhashi|1963}}</ref> The remaining real Lorentz groups can be deduced by Flensted-Jensen's method of descent, as can other semisimple Lie groups of real rank one.<ref>{{harvnb|Loeb|1979}}</ref> Flensted-Jensen's method of descent also applies to the treatment of real semisimple Lie groups for which the Lie algebras are [[real form (Lie theory)#Normal real form|normal real forms]] of complex semisimple Lie algebras.<ref name="FlenstedJensen1978" /> The special case of SL(N,'''R''') is treated in detail in {{harvtxt|Jorgenson|Lang|2001}}; this group is also the normal real form of SL(N,'''C''').

The approach of {{harvtxt|Flensted-Jensen|1978}} applies to a wide class of real semisimple Lie groups of arbitrary real rank and yields the explicit product form of the Plancherel measure on <math>\mathfrak{a}</math>* without using Harish-Chandra's expansion of the spherical functions φ<sub>λ</sub>
in terms of his c-function, discussed below. Although less general, it gives a simpler approach to the Plancherel theorem for this class of groups.

===Complex semisimple Lie groups===

If ''G'' is a complex semisimple Lie group, it is the [[complexification]] of its maximal compact subgroup ''U'', a compact semisimple Lie group. If <math>{\mathfrak
g}</math> and <math>\mathfrak{u}</math> are their Lie algebras, then

:<math> \mathfrak{g} = \mathfrak{u} \oplus i\mathfrak{u}.</math>

Let ''T'' be a [[maximal torus]] in ''U'' with Lie algebra <math>\mathfrak{t}</math>. Then setting

:<math>A= \exp i \mathfrak{t}, \,\, P= \exp i \mathfrak{u},</math>

there is the [[Cartan decomposition]]:

:<math>G=P\cdot U = UAU.</math>

The finite-dimensional irreducible representations π<sub>λ</sub> of ''U'' are indexed by certain λ in <math>\mathfrak{t}^*</math>.<ref>These are indexed by highest weights shifted by half the sum of the positive roots.</ref> The corresponding character formula and dimension formula of [[Hermann Weyl]] give explicit formulas for

:<math>\chi_\lambda(e^X)={\rm Tr}\, \pi_\lambda(e^X), (X\in \mathfrak{t})),\,\,\, d(\lambda)={\rm dim}\, \pi_\lambda.</math>

These formulas, initially defined on <math>\mathfrak{t}^*\times \mathfrak{t}</math> and <math>\mathfrak{t}^*</math>, extend holomorphic to their 
complexifications. Moreover,

:<math>\chi_\lambda(e^X)={\sum_{\sigma \in W} {\rm sign}(\sigma) e^{i\lambda(\sigma X)}\over \delta(e^X)},</math>

where ''W'' is the [[Weyl group]] <math> W =N_U(T)/T</math> and δ(''e''<sup>''X''</sup>) is given by a product formula (Weyl's denominator formula) which extends holomorphically to the complexification of
<math>\mathfrak{t}</math>. There is a similar product formula for ''d''(λ), a polynomial in λ.

On the complex group ''G'', the integral of a ''U''-biinvariant function ''F'' can be evaluated as

:<math>\int_G F(g) \, dg = {1\over |W|} \int_{\mathfrak{a}} F(e^X)\, |\delta(e^X)|^2 \, dX.</math>

where <math>\mathfrak{a}=i\mathfrak{t}</math>.

The spherical functions of ''G'' are labelled by λ in <math>\mathfrak{a}=i\mathfrak{t}^*</math> and given by the Harish-Chandra-Berezin formula<ref>{{harvnb|Helgason|1984|pages=423–433}}</ref>

:<math> \Phi_\lambda(e^X) = {\chi_\lambda(e^X)\over d(\lambda)}.</math>

They are the matrix coefficients of the irreducible spherical principal series of ''G'' induced from the character of the [[Borel subgroup]] of ''G'' corresponding to λ; these representations are irreducible and can all be realized on L<sup>2</sup>(''U'' / ''T'').

The spherical transform of a ''U''-biinvariant function ''F'' is given by

:<math> \tilde{F}(\lambda)=\int_G F(g) \Phi_{-\lambda}(g)\, dg</math>

and the spherical inversion formula by

:<math> F(g) ={1\over |W|}\int_{{\mathfrak a}^*} \tilde{F}(\lambda)\Phi_\lambda(g) |d(\lambda)|^2 \, d\,\lambda=
\int_{{\mathfrak a}^*_+} \tilde{F}(\lambda)\Phi_\lambda(g) |d(\lambda)|^2 \, d\,\lambda,</math>

where <math>{\mathfrak a}^*_+</math> is a [[Weyl chamber]]. In fact the result follows from the [[Fourier inversion formula]] on <math>\mathfrak{a}</math> since<ref>{{harvnb|Flensted-Jensen|1978|page=115}}</ref>

:<math>d(\lambda)\delta(e^X)\Phi_\lambda(e^X)=\sum_{\sigma\in W} {\rm sign}(\sigma) e^{i\lambda(X)},</math>

so that <math>\displaystyle\overline{d(\lambda)}\tilde{F}(\lambda)</math> is just the [[Fourier transform]] of <math>\displaystyle F(e^X)\delta(e^X)</math>.

Note that the [[symmetric space]] ''G'' / ''U'' has as ''compact dual''<ref>{{harvnb|Helgason|1978}}</ref> the compact symmetric space ''U'' x ''U'' / ''U'', where ''U'' is the diagonal subgroup. The spherical functions for the latter space, which can be identified with ''U'' itself, are the
normalized characters χ<sub>λ</sub>/''d''(λ) indexed by lattice points in the interior of <math>{\mathfrak a}^*_+</math> and the role of ''A'' is played by ''T''. The spherical transform of ''f'' of a [[class function]] on ''U'' is given by

:<math> \tilde{f}(\lambda)=\int_U f(u){\overline{\chi_\lambda(u)}\over d(\lambda)} \,du</math>

and the spherical inversion formula now follows from the theory of [[Fourier series]] on ''T'':

:<math> f(u)=\sum_{\lambda} \tilde{f}(\lambda) {\chi_\lambda(u)\over d(\lambda)} d(\lambda)^2.</math>

There is an evident duality between these formulas and those for the non-compact dual.<ref>The spherical inversion formula for ''U'' is equivalent to the statement that the functions <math>\chi_\lambda d(\lambda)^{-1/2}</math> form an [[orthonormal basis]] for the class functions.</ref>

===Real semisimple Lie groups===

Let ''G''<sub>0</sub> be a [[Real form (Lie theory)#Normal real form|normal real form]] of the complex semisimple Lie group ''G'', the fixed points of an involution σ, conjugate linear on the Lie algebra of ''G''. Let τ be a Cartan involution of ''G''<sub>0</sub> extended to an involution of ''G'', complex linear on its Lie algebra, chosen to commute with σ. The fixed point subgroup of τσ is a compact real form ''U'' of ''G'', intersecting ''G''<sub>0</sub> in a maximal compact subgroup ''K''<sub>0</sub>. The fixed point subgroup of τ is ''K'', the complexification of ''K''<sub>0</sub>. Let ''G''<sub>0</sub>= ''K''<sub>0</sub>·''P''<sub>0</sub> be the corresponding Cartan decomposition of ''G''<sub>0</sub> and let ''A'' be a maximal Abelian subgroup of ''P''<sub>0</sub>. {{harvtxt|Flensted-Jensen|1978}} proved that

:<math>\displaystyle G= KA_+U,</math>

where ''A''<sub>+</sub> is the image of the closure of a Weyl chamber in <math>\mathfrak{a}</math> under the exponential map. 
Moreover,

:<math> K\backslash G/U = A_+.</math>

Since

:<math> K_0\backslash G_0/K_0 = A_+</math>

it follows that there is a canonical identification between ''K'' \ ''G'' / ''U'', ''K''<sub>0</sub> \ ''G''<sub>0</sub> /''K''<sub>0</sub> and ''A''<sub>+</sub>. Thus ''K''<sub>0</sub>-biinvariant functions on ''G''<sub>0</sub> can be identified with functions on ''A''<sub>+</sub> as can
functions on ''G'' that are left invariant under ''K'' and right invariant under ''U''. Let ''f'' be a function in 
<math>C^\infty_c(K_0\backslash G_0 /K_0)</math> and define ''Mf'' in
<math>C^\infty_c(U\backslash G /U)</math> by

:<math> \displaystyle Mf(a)=\int_U f(ua^2) \,du.</math>

Here a third Cartan decomposition of ''G'' = ''UAU'' has been used to identify ''U'' \ ''G'' / ''U'' with ''A''<sub>+</sub>.

Let Δ be the Laplacian on ''G''<sub>0</sub>/''K''<sub>0</sub> and let Δ<sub>c</sub> be the Laplacian on ''G''/''U''. Then

:<math> \displaystyle 4M\Delta = \Delta_c M.</math>

For ''F'' in <math>C^\infty_c(U\backslash G /U)</math>, define ''M''*''F'' in <math>C^\infty_c(K_0\backslash G_0 /K_0)</math> by

:<math>\displaystyle M^*F(a^2)=\int_K F(ga) \, dg.</math>

Then ''M'' and ''M''* satisfy the duality relations

:<math> \displaystyle \int_{G/U} (Mf) \cdot F = \int_{G_0/K_0} f\cdot (M^*F).</math>

In particular

:<math> \displaystyle M^*\Delta_c= 4\Delta M^*.</math>

There is a similar compatibility for other operators in the center of the [[universal enveloping algebra]] of ''G''<sub>0</sub>. It follows from
the eigenfunction characterisation of spherical functions that <math> M^*\Phi_{2\lambda}</math> is proportional to φ<sub>λ</sub> on ''G''<sub>0</sub>, the constant of proportionality being given by

:<math> b(\lambda)=M^*\Phi_{2\lambda}(1)=\int_K \Phi_{2\lambda}(k)\, dk. </math>

Moreover, in this case<ref>{{harvnb|Flensted-Jensen|page=133}}</ref>

:<math>\displaystyle (M^* F)^\sim(\lambda)= \tilde{F}(2\lambda).</math>

If ''f'' = ''M''*''F'', then the spherical inversion formula for ''F'' on ''G'' implies that for ''f'' on ''G''<sub>0</sub>:<ref>{{harvnb|Flensted-Jensen|1978|page=133}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Helgason|1984|page=490–491}}</ref>

:<math> f(g)= \int_{\mathfrak{a}^*_+} \tilde{f}(\lambda) \varphi_\lambda(g) \,\, 2^{{\rm dim}\, A}\cdot |b(\lambda)|\cdot |d(2\lambda)|^2 \,d\lambda, </math>

since

:<math>f(g)= M^*F(g)= \int_{\mathfrak{a}_+^*} \tilde{F}(2\lambda) M^*\Phi_{2\lambda}(g) 2^{{\rm dim}\, A} |d(2\lambda)|^2 \, d\lambda
= \int_{\mathfrak{a}_+^*} \tilde{f}(\lambda) \varphi_\lambda(g) \,\,b(\lambda) 2^{{\rm dim}\, A} |d(2\lambda)|^2 \, d\lambda.
</math>

The direct calculation of the integral for ''b''(λ), generalising the computation of {{harvtxt|Godement|1957}} for SL(2,'''R'''), was left as an open problem by {{harvtxt|Flensted-Jensen|1978}}.<ref>''b''(λ) can be written as integral over ''A''<sub>0</sub> where ''K'' = ''K''<sub>0</sub> ''A''<sub>0</sub> ''K''<sub>0</sub> is the Cartan decomposition of ''K''. The integral then becomes an alternating sum of multidimensional Godement-type integrals, whose combinatorics is governed by that of the [[Zonal spherical function#Cartan–Helgason theorem|Cartan-Helgason theorem]] for ''U''/''K''<sub>0</sub>. An equivalent computation that arises in the theory of the [[Radon transform]] has been discussed by {{harvtxt|Beerends|1987}}, {{harvtxt|Stade|1999}} and {{harvtxt|Gindikin|2008}}.</ref> An explicit product formula for ''b''(λ) was known from the prior determination of the Plancherel measure by
{{harvtxt|Harish-Chandra|1966}}, giving<ref>{{harvnb|Helgason|1984}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Beerends|1987|page=4–5}}</ref>

:<math> b(\lambda) =C\cdot d(2\lambda)^{-1}\cdot \prod_{\alpha>0} \tanh {\pi(\alpha,\lambda)\over (\alpha,\alpha)},</math>

where α ranges over the positive roots of the [[root system]] in <math>\mathfrak{a}</math> and ''C'' is a normalising constant, given as a quotient of products of [[Gamma function]]s.

==Harish-Chandra's Plancherel theorem==
Let ''G'' be a noncompact connected real semisimple Lie group with finite center. Let <math>\mathfrak{g}</math> denote its Lie algebra. Let ''K'' be a maximal compact subgroup
given as the subgroup of fixed points of a Cartan involution σ. Let <math>\mathfrak{g}_{\pm}</math> be the ±1 eigenspaces of σ in <math>\mathfrak{g}</math>, so that <math>\mathfrak{k}=\mathfrak{g}_+</math> is the Lie algebra of ''K'' and <math>\mathfrak{p}=\mathfrak{g}_-</math> give the Cartan decomposition

:<math>\mathfrak{g}=\mathfrak{k}+\mathfrak{p},\,\, G=\exp \mathfrak{p}\cdot K.</math>

Let <math>\mathfrak {a}</math> be a maximal Abelian subalgebra of <math>\mathfrak{p}</math> and for α in <math>\mathfrak {a}^*</math> let

:<math>\mathfrak{g}_\alpha=\{X\in \mathfrak{g}: [H,X]=\alpha(H)X\,\,(H\in \mathfrak{a})\}.</math>

If α ≠ 0 and <math>\mathfrak{g}_\alpha\ne (0)</math>, then α is called a ''restricted root'' and 
''m''<sub>α</sub> = dim <math>\mathfrak{g}_\alpha</math> is called its ''multiplicity''. Let ''A'' = exp <math>\mathfrak {a}</math>, so
that ''G'' = ''KAK''.The restriction of the [[Killing form]] defines an inner product on <math>\mathfrak{p}</math> and hence <math>\mathfrak{a}</math>, which allows <math>\mathfrak{a}^*</math> to be identified with <math>\mathfrak{a}</math>. With respect to this inner product, the restricted roots Σ give a [[root system]]. Its [[Weyl group]] can be identified with
<math>W=N_K(A)/C_K(A)</math>. A choice of positive roots defines a Weyl chamber <math>\mathfrak{a}_+^*</math>. The ''reduced root system'' Σ<sub>0</sub> consists of roots α such that α/2 is not a root.

Defining the spherical functions φ<sub> λ</sub> as above for λ in <math>\mathfrak {a}^*</math>, the spherical transform of ''f'' in C<sub>c</sub><sup>∞</sup>(''K'' \ ''G'' / ''K'') is defined by

:<math>\tilde{f}(\lambda)=\int_G f(g) \varphi_{-\lambda}(g)\, dg.</math>

The '''spherical inversion formula''' states that

:<math>f(g)=\int_{\mathfrak{a}^*_+} \tilde{f}(\lambda) \varphi_\lambda(g)\, |c(\lambda)|^{-2}\, d\lambda,</math>

where '''Harish-Chandra's c-function''' '''c'''(λ) is defined by<ref>{{harvnb|Helgason|year=1984|page=447}}</ref>

:<math>c(\lambda)=c_0\cdot\prod_{\alpha\in \Sigma_0^+} {2^{-i(\lambda,\alpha_0)}
\Gamma(i(\lambda,\alpha_0))\over
\Gamma({1\over 2}[{1\over 2} m_\alpha + 1 +i(\lambda,\alpha_0)])
\Gamma({1\over 2}[{1\over 2} m_{\alpha} + m_{2\alpha} +i(\lambda,\alpha_0)])}</math>

with <math>\alpha_0=(\alpha,\alpha)^{-1} \alpha</math> and the constant ''c''<sub>0</sub> chosen so that '''c'''(–''i''ρ) = 1 where

:<math> \rho={1\over 2} \sum_{\alpha\in \Sigma^+} m_\alpha \alpha.</math>

The '''Plancherel theorem for spherical functions''' states that the map

:<math>W:f\mapsto \tilde{f},\,\,\,\ L^2(K\backslash G /K) \rightarrow L^2(\mathfrak{a}_+^*, |c(\lambda)|^{-2}\, d\lambda)</math>

is unitary and transforms convolution by <math> f\in L^1(K\backslash G/K)</math> into 
multiplication by <math>\tilde{f}</math>.

==Harish-Chandra's spherical function expansion==
Since ''G'' = ''KAK'', functions on ''G''/''K'' that are invariant under ''K'' can be identified with functions on ''A'', and hence <math>\mathfrak a</math>, that are invariant under the Weyl group ''W''. In particular since the Laplacian Δ on ''G''/''K'' commutes with the action of ''G'', it defines a second order differential operator ''L'' on <math>\mathfrak a</math>, invariant under ''W'', called the ''radial part of the Laplacian''. In general
if ''X'' is in <math>\mathfrak{a}</math>, it defines a first order differential operator (or vector field) by

:<math>Xf(y)={d\over dt} f(y+tX)|_{t=0}.</math>

''L'' can be expressed in terms of these operators by the formula<ref>{{harvnb|Helgason|1984|page=267}}</ref>

:<math>\displaystyle L=\Delta_{\mathfrak{a}} -\sum_{\alpha>0} m_\alpha \, \coth \alpha \, A_\alpha,</math>

where ''A''<sub>α</sub> in <math>\mathfrak{a}</math> is defined by

:<math>\displaystyle (A_\alpha,X)=\alpha(X)</math>

and

:<math>\Delta_{\mathfrak{a}}=-\sum X_i^2</math>

is the Laplacian on <math>\mathfrak{a}</math>, corresponding to any choice of orthonormal basis (''X''<sub>''i''</sub>).

Thus

:<math>L=L_0 -\sum_{\alpha>0} m_\alpha\, (\coth \alpha -1) A_\alpha,</math>

where

:<math>L_0=\Delta_{\mathfrak{a}} - \sum_{\alpha>0} A_\alpha,</math>

so that ''L'' can be regarded as a perturbation of the constant-coefficient operator ''L''<sub>0</sub>.

Now the spherical function φ<sub>λ</sub> is an eigenfunction of the Laplacian:

:<math>\Delta\varphi_\lambda=(\|\lambda\|^2 + \|\rho\|^2)\varphi_\lambda</math>

and therefore of ''L'', when viewed as a ''W''-invariant function on <math>\mathfrak{a}</math>.

Since ''e''<sup>''i''λ–ρ</sup> and its transforms under ''W'' are eigenfunctions of ''L''<sub>0</sub> with the same eigenvalue, 
it is natural look for a formula for φ<sub>λ</sub> in terms of a perturbation series

:<math>f_\lambda=e^{i\lambda -\rho}\sum_{\mu\in \Lambda} a_\mu(\lambda) e^{-\mu},</math>

with Λ the cone of all non-negative integer combinations of positive roots, and the transforms of ''f''<sub>λ</sub> under ''W''. The expansion

:<math>\displaystyle \coth x-1 =2 \sum_{m>0} e^{-2mx},</math>

leads to a recursive formula for the coefficients ''a''<sub>μ</sub>(λ). In particular they are uniquely determined and the
series and its derivatives converges absolutely on <math>\mathfrak{a}_+</math>, a [[fundamental domain]] for ''W''. Remarkably
it turns out that ''f''<sub>λ</sub> is also an eigenfunction of the other ''G''-invariant differential operators on ''G''/''K'', each of
which induces a ''W''-invariant differential operator on <math>\mathfrak{a}</math>.

It follows that φ<sub>λ</sub> can be expressed in terms as a linear combination of ''f''<sub>λ</sub> and its transforms under ''W'':<ref>{{harvnb|Helgason|1984|page=430}}</ref>

:<math>\varphi_\lambda=\sum_{s\in W} c(s\lambda) f_{s\lambda}.</math>

Here '''c'''(λ) is '''Harish-Chandra's c-function'''. It describes the asymptotic behaviour of φ<sub>λ</sub> in <math>\mathfrak{a}_+</math>, 
since<ref>{{harvnb|Helgason|1984|page=435}}</ref>

:<math>\varphi_\lambda(e^tX) \sim c(\lambda) e^{(i\lambda -\rho)Xt}</math>

for ''X'' in <math>\mathfrak{a}_+</math> and ''t''>0 large.

Harish-Chandra obtained a second integral formula for φ<sub>λ</sub> and hence '''c'''(λ) using the [[Bruhat decomposition]] of ''G'':<ref>{{harvnb|Helgason|1978|page=403}}</ref>

:<math>G = \bigcup_{s\in W} B s B,</math>

where ''B'' = ''MAN'' and the union is disjoint. Taking the [[Coxeter element]] ''s''<sub>0</sub> of ''W'', the unique element mapping <math>\mathfrak{a}_+</math> onto <math>-\mathfrak{a}_+</math>, it follows that σ(''N'') has a dense open orbit ''G''/''B''=''K''/''M''
whose complement is a union of cells of strictly smaller dimension and therefore has measure zero. It follows that the integral formula
for φ<sub>λ</sub> initially defined over ''K''/''M''

:<math>\varphi_\lambda(g) = \int_{K/M} \lambda^\prime(gk)^{-1}\, dk.</math>

can be transferred to σ(''N''):<ref>{{harvnb|Helgason|1984|page=436}}</ref>

:<math>\varphi_\lambda(e^X)=e^{i\lambda -\rho} \int_{\sigma(N)} {\overline{\lambda^\prime(n)} \over \lambda^\prime(e^Xne^{-X})} \, dn,</math>

for ''X'' in <math>\mathfrak{a}</math>.

Since

:<math>\lim_{t\rightarrow \infty} e^{tX}ne^{-tX}= 1</math>

for ''X'' in <math>\mathfrak{a}_+</math>, the asymptotic behaviour of φ<sub>λ</sub> can be read off from this integral, leading to the formula:<ref>{{harvnb|Halgason|1984|page=447}}</ref>

:<math> c(\lambda)=\int_{\sigma(N)} \overline{\lambda^\prime(n)}\, dn.</math>

==Harish-Chandra's c-function==

{{main article|Harish-Chandra's c-function}}

The many roles of Harish-Chandra's '''c'''-function in [[non-commutative harmonic analysis]] are surveyed in {{harvtxt|Helgason|2000}}. Although it was originally introduced by Harish-Chandra in the asymptotic expansions of spherical functions, discussed above, it was also soon understood to be intimately related to intertwining operators between induced representations, first studied in this context by {{harvtxt|Bruhat|1957}}. These operators exhibit the unitary equivalence between π<sub>λ</sub> and π<sub>''s''λ</sub> for ''s'' in the Weyl group and a '''c'''-function '''c'''<sub>''s''</sub>(λ) can be attached to each such operator: namely the value at ''1'' of the intertwining operator applied to ξ<sub>0</sub>, the constant function 1, in L<sup>2</sup>(''K''/''M'').<ref>{{harvnb|Knapp|2001}}, Chapter VII</ref> Equivalently, since ξ<sub>0</sub> is up to scalar multiplication the unique vector fixed by ''K'', it is an eigenvector of the intertwining operator with eigenvalue '''c'''<sub>''s''</sub>(λ).
These operators all act on the same space L<sup>2</sup>(''K''/''M''), which can be identified with the representation induced from
the 1-dimensional representation defined by λ on ''MAN''. Once ''A'' has been chosen, the compact subgroup ''M'' is uniquely determined as the centraliser of ''A'' in ''K''. The nilpotent subgroup ''N'', however, depends on a choice of a Weyl chamber in <math>\mathfrak{a}^*</math>, the various choices being permuted by the Weyl group ''W'' = ''M'' ' / ''M'', where ''M'' ' is the normaliser of ''A'' in ''K''. The '''standard intertwining operator''' corresponding to (''s'', λ) is defined on the induced representation by<ref>{{harvnb|Knapp|2001|page=177}}</ref>

:<math> \displaystyle A(s,\lambda)F(k)=\int_{\sigma(N)\cap s^{-1}Ns} F(ksn)\, dn,</math>

where σ is the Cartan involution. It satisfies the intertwining relation

:<math>\displaystyle A(s,\lambda)\pi_\lambda(g) =\pi_{s\lambda}(g) A(s,\lambda).</math>

The key property of the intertwining operators and their integrals is the multiplicative cocycle property<ref>{{harvnb|Knapp|2001|page=182}}</ref>

:<math> \displaystyle A(s_1s_2,\lambda)=A(s_1,s_2\lambda)A(s_2,\lambda),</math>

whenever

:<math>\ell(s_1s_2)=\ell(s_1)+\ell(s_2)</math>

for the length function on the Weyl group associated with the choice of Weyl chamber. For ''s'' in ''W'', this is the number of chambers
crossed by the straight line segment between ''X'' and ''sX'' for any point ''X'' in the interior of the chamber. The unique element of greatest length
''s''<sub>0</sub>, namely the number of positive restricted roots, is the unique element that carries the Weyl chamber <math>\mathfrak{a}_+^*</math> onto <math>-\mathfrak{a}_+^*</math>. By Harish-Chandra's integral formula, it corresponds to Harish-Chandra's '''c'''-function:

:<math> c(\lambda)=c_{s_0}(\lambda).</math>

The '''c'''-functions are in general defined by the equation

:<math> \displaystyle A(s,\lambda)\xi_0 =c_s(\lambda)\xi_0,</math>

where ξ<sub>0</sub> is the constant function 1 in L<sup>2</sup>(''K''/''M''). The cocycle property of the intertwining operators implies a similar multiplicative property for the '''c'''-functions:

:<math> c_{s_1s_2}(\lambda) =c_{s_1}(s_2 \lambda)c_{s_2}(\lambda)</math>

provided

:<math>\ell(s_1s_2)=\ell(s_1)+\ell(s_2).</math>

This reduces the computation of '''c'''<sub>''s''</sub> to the case when ''s'' = ''s''<sub>α</sub>, the reflection in a (simple) root α, the so-called 
"rank-one reduction" of {{harvtxt|Gindikin|Karpelevič|1962}}. In fact the integral involves only the closed connected subgroup ''G''<sup>α</sup> corresponding to the Lie subalgebra generated by <math>\mathfrak{g}_{\pm \alpha}</math> where α lies in Σ<sub>0</sub><sup>+</sup>.<ref>{{harvnb|Helgason|1978|page=407}}</ref> Then ''G''<sup>α</sup> is a real semisimple Lie group with real rank one, i.e. dim ''A''<sup>α</sup> = 1,
and '''c'''<sub>''s''</sub> is just the Harish-Chandra '''c'''-function of ''G''<sup>α</sup>. In this case the '''c'''-function can be computed directly by various means:

*by noting that φ<sub>λ</sub> can be expressed in terms of the [[hypergeometric function]] for which the asymptotic expansion is known from the classical formulas of [[Carl Friedrich Gauss|Gauss]] for the [[Hypergeometric differential equation#Connection coefficients|connection coefficients]];<ref name="HarishChandra1958" /><ref>{{harvnb|Helagson|1984|page=484}}</ref>
*by directly computing the integral, which can be expressed as an integral in two variables and hence a product of two [[beta function]]s.<ref>{{harvnb|Helgason|1978|page=414}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Helgason|1984|page=437}}</ref>

This yields the following formula:

:<math>c_{s_\alpha}(\lambda)=c_0{2^{-i(\lambda,\alpha_0)}\Gamma(i(\lambda,\alpha_0))\over\Gamma({1\over 2} ({1\over 2}m_\alpha + 1+ i(\lambda,\alpha_0)) \Gamma({1\over 2} ({1\over 2}m_\alpha + m_{2\alpha} + i(\lambda,\alpha_0))},</math>

where

:<math>c_0=2^{m_\alpha/2 + m_{2\alpha}}\Gamma({1\over 2} (m_\alpha+m_{2\alpha} +1)).</math>

The general [[Gindikin–Karpelevich formula]] for '''c'''(λ) is an immediate consequence of this formula and the multiplicative properties of '''c'''<sub>''s''</sub>(λ).

==Paley–Wiener theorem==
The Paley-Wiener theorem generalizes the [[Paley-Wiener theorem|classical Paley-Wiener theorem]] by characterizing the spherical transforms of smooth ''K''-bivariant functions of compact support on ''G''. It is a necessary and sufficient condition that the spherical transform be ''W''-invariant and that there is an ''R'' > 0 such that for each ''N'' there is an estimate

:<math>|\tilde{f}(\lambda)|\le C_N (1+|\lambda|)^{-N} e^{R|{\rm Im}\, \lambda|}.</math>

In this case ''f'' is supported in the closed ball of radius ''R'' about the origin in ''G''/''K''.

This was proved by Helgason and Gangolli ({{harvtxt|Helgason|1970}} pg. 37).

The theorem was later proved by {{harvtxt|Flensted-Jensen|1986}} independently of the spherical inversion theorem, using a modification of his method of reduction to the complex case.<ref>The second statement on supports follows from Flensted-Jensen's proof by using the explicit methods associated with
[[Kostant polynomial]]s instead of the results of Mustapha Rais.</ref>

==Rosenberg's proof of inversion formula==
{{harvtxt|Rosenberg|1977}} noticed that the Paley-Wiener theorem and the spherical inversion theorem could be proved simultaneously, by a trick which 
considerably simplified previous proofs.

The first step of his proof consists in showing directly that the inverse transform, defined using Harish-Chandra's '''c'''-function, defines a function supported in the closed ball of radius ''R'' about the origin if the Paley-Wiener estimate is satisfied. This follows
because the integrand defining the inverse transform extends to a meromorphic function on the [[complexification]] of <math>\mathfrak{a}^*</math>; the integral can be shifted to <math>\mathfrak{a}^* + i\mu t</math> for μ in <math>\mathfrak{a}^*_+</math> and ''t'' > 0. Using Harish-Chandra's expansion
of φ<sub>λ</sub> and the formulas for '''c'''(λ) in terms of [[Gamma function]]s, the integral can be bounded for ''t'' large and hence can be shown to vanish outside the closed ball of radius ''R'' about the origin.<ref>{{harvnb|Helgason|1984|pages=452–453}}</ref>

This part of the Paley-Wiener theorem shows that

:<math>\displaystyle T(f)=\int_{\mathfrak{a}_+^*} \tilde{f}(\lambda) |c(\lambda)|^{-2} \, d\lambda</math>

defines a distribution on ''G''/''K'' with support at the origin ''o''. A further estimate for the integral shows that it is in fact given by a measure and that therefore there is a constant ''C'' such that

:<math> \displaystyle T(f)=Cf(o).</math>

By applying this result to

:<math>f_1(g)=\int_K f(x^{-1}kg)\, dk,</math>

it follows that

:<math> Cf=\int_{\mathfrak{a}_+^*} \tilde{f}(\lambda) \varphi_\lambda |c(\lambda)|^{-2} \, d\lambda.</math>

A further scaling argument allows the inequality ''C'' = ''1'' to be deduced from the Plancherel theorem and Paley-Wiener theorem on <math>\mathfrak{a}</math>.<ref>{{harvnb|Rosenberg|1977}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Helgason|1984|page=588–589}}</ref>

==Schwartz functions==
The Harish-Chandra Schwartz space can be defined as<ref>{{harvnb|Anker|1991|page=347}}</ref>

:<math>\mathcal{S}(K\backslash G/K)=\{f\in C^\infty(G/K)^K:\sup_{x} |(1+d(x,o))^m (\Delta + I)^n f(x)|<\infty\}.</math>

Under the spherical transform it is mapped onto <math>\mathcal{S}(\mathfrak{a}^*)^W</math>, the space of ''W''-invariant
[[Schwartz function]]s on <math>\mathfrak{a}^*</math>.

The original proof of Harish-Chandra was a long argument by induction.<ref name="HarishChandra1958" /><ref name="HarishChandra1958a" /><ref>{{harvnb|Helgason|1984|page=489}}</ref> {{harvtxt|Anker|1991}} found a short and simple proof, allowing the result to be deduced directly from versions of the Paley-Wiener and spherical inversion formula. He proved that the spherical transform of a Harish-Chandra Schwartz function is a classical Schwartz function. His key observation was then to show that the inverse transform was continuous on the Paley-Wiener space endowed with classical Schwartz space [[seminorm]]s, using classical estimates.
